Award.AwardTitle: In Situ Form Metrology in Manufacturing by Combining Engineered Optical Scattering and Photogrammetry

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
The research objective of this award is to apply mapping sciences from the disciplines of photogrammetry and remote sensing to realize a new dimensional measurement capability in manufacturing engineering that is inexpensive, non-contact, remote, and applicable to in situ measurements. The approach is to use a laser beam or a beam pattern generated with a diffractive optical element and scatter this beam(s) either from the part being manufactured itself, or from engineered structures placed into the manufacturing environment. Photogrammetry will be used to determine absolute coordinates of reflected spots in the environment and this information will be mapped back to the desired dimensional information. Effectively, the part measurement is moved out away from the part by using photogrammetry to measure the optical scattering from the part.

If successful, this method will open a new field of metrology research. Success will mean demonstrating dimensional measurements with uncertainty of 1 part in 100,000 in two important manufacturing applications, representing a significant technical and economic advance: (1) on machine metrology of free-form diamond machined surfaces and (2) in situ and dynamic metrology of large continuous polishing platens used for high precision optic polishing. The research necessitates graduate education experience in optics, precision metrology, and mechanical engineering. The visibly appealing features of the measurement will be exploited and learning tools developed for both students and the general public. This will include modules for undergraduate and graduate advanced optics lab courses, a demo module for the general public for use by local student chapters in optics and engineering societies, and a module for use at advertisement and recruitment booths at professional society meetings.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project focused on a new measurement strategy for precision manufacturing.  It applied mapping sciences from the disciplines of photogrammetry and remote sensing to realize a new dimensional measurement capability in manufacturing engineering that is inexpensive, non-contact, remote, and applicable to in situ measurements. 

Intellectual Merit

The primary intellectual merit research advances were the following:

  1. Vector analysis algorithms to transform absolute coordinates of reflected spots to target angular orientation.
  2. Optimized diffractive structures to amplify the number of scattered spots (reduce uncertainty through averaging) to facilitate dynamic tracking and image processing.
  3. Application of advanced optical simulation packages that will allow us to completely numerically simulate the measurement process. This allowed rigorous validation of measurement uncertainty, camera calibration, and Monte Carlo analyses to assess and overcome measurement limitations

Broader Impact (Economic)

The method developed here opens a new field of metrology research. We demonstrated the new method by focusing on 2 manufacturing applications: (1) on machine metrology of free-form diamond machined surfaces and (2) in situ and dynamic metrology of large continuous polishing (CP) platens used for precision optic polishing. The results were positive in both areas.  the measurement goal was not quite realized but the detailed uncertainty analysis shows that the goal is realistic. There are many other potential variations and applications that will be pursued in future research.
